target_text: "Software quality is both outcome and process. We measure the outcome by product quality; its ability to meet business needs and has no defects. The process is how we create and deliver the software. In agile, this is a continuous improvement process. It gets better by continuously examining the way we work, we learn and change for the better. In agile, we always experiment to come up with better ways."

Role.Subject: Geography
Role.positionality:
Five dimensions
- Role Identity: Product Owner
- Intended Study Level: Masters
- Subject (QS): Geography
- Research Interest (NSF): Economics
- Biases/Assumptions: Epistemological (pragmatic-positivist)

Positionality statement
I am a Product Owner pursuing a Master’s in Geography, bringing product strategy, stakeholder coordination, and spatial thinking to my research. I study economic geography to translate spatial-economic patterns into actionable insights for decision-makers. Epistemologically, I lean pragmatic-positivist: I privilege measurable evidence, causal inference, and implementable models, while recognizing their limits. This positionality leads me to frame questions around optimization and user value and to read user responses as requirements, which can underweight lived experience. I mitigate by triangulating quantitative analysis with participatory methods and reflecting on how question framing and responses shape interpretation.

Codebook.role: Reflexive Software Engineering Researcher (PhD Candidate; CS-SE/HCI; NSF: Human-Centered Computing; Bias: pro-agile, socio-technical quality)

codebook.justification: I foreground process–outcome coupling; [Software quality is both outcome and process.] frames quality as a socio-technical construct rather than a single metric.
From an HCI/SE lens, value is co-constructed; [ability to meet business needs] signals negotiated requirements beyond purely defect counts.
My pro-agile bias privileges kaizen; [In agile, this is a continuous improvement process.] casts quality as iterative learning over static compliance.
I read an empirical stance; [In agile, we always experiment to come up with better ways.] implies hypothesis-driven change and adaptive governance.
